print_settings.Notes:: This is important, so I'm repeating myself..... Do not be alarmed if the rollers fuse slightly to each other. I break them apart with small needle node pliers. Just insert the pliers in to the gaps between the rollers and twist the pliers. This is usually enough to separate them. Do this for each roller and the bearing will spin freely.

title: Fully Printable Roller Bearing (NO SUPPORTS NEEDED)

description.text:
This is a roller bearing I designed because I was tired of printing support for ball bearing designs.

This was meant to be more of a fidget than a bearing that you'd use on something (that's why it has textured rings), however, it works very well as a bearing under modest loads.

I have scaled these up and down.
Smallest red bearing in the photos is 30mm outer diameter.
Larger red bearing is 40mm OD
Green and Glow Bearings are 43mm (native size).

I have scaled up to 70mm and they print fine. The larger (60mm or larger) sizes print without any fusing of the rollers. Curiously, the smallest (30mm) bearing spins the longest. It fused initially but once separated, spins amazingly well.

Please post your comments and makes!

Do not be alarmed if the rollers fuse slightly to each other. I break them apart with small needle nose pliers. Just insert the pliers in to the gaps between the rollers and twist the pliers. This is usually enough to separate them. Do this for each roller and the bearing will spin freely.

Note: I have found that Hatchbox PLA prints very well. However, Hatchbox Silver PLA tends to fuse far more than other colors, or even other brands. If printing this bearing in Hatchbox Silver PLA, you might have to print it at 50mm or larger

Printer:

Hatchbox Alpha

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I have printed these at 20%, 50%, and 100% infill. All seem to work fine.

This can be a tough print because the tolerances are very tight. Make sure your printer is dialed in. Also, I printed mine at 195C with a bed temp of 60C. Try to use the coldest temps you can while still maintaining good layer and bed adhesion. Otherwise, you may encounter some curling of the walls of the rollers during the first 25% of the print.

This is important, so I'm repeating myself..... Do not be alarmed if the rollers fuse slightly to each other. I break them apart with small needle node pliers. Just insert the pliers in to the gaps between the rollers and twist the pliers. This is usually enough to separate them. Do this for each roller and the bearing will spin freely.

Lubrication

After you separate any fused rollers, I like to spin the bearing a bit to break it in. This is to loosen or wear down any stray bits of plastic. I then lubricate it with PTFE spray or fluid. I spin it while it's wet with the PTFE a few times and then let it dry. Once dry, these bearings really spin very well.

author: mxracer20011106

description.text:
3-D printable open source desktop nutating mixer, which provides a fixed 20° platform tilt angle for a gentle three-dimensional (gyrating) agitation of chemical or biological samples (e.g., DNA or blood samples) without foam formation. The custom components for the nutating mixer are designed using open source FreeCAD software to enable customization. All of the non-readily available components can be fabricated with a low-cost RepRap 3-D printer using an open source software tool chain from common thermoplastics. All of the designs are open sourced and can be configured to add more functionality to the equipment in the future. It is relatively easy to assemble and is accessible to both the science education of younger students as well as state-of-the-art research laboratories. Overall, the open source nutating mixer can be fabricated with US$37 in parts, which is 1/10th of the cost of proprietary nutating mixers with similar capabilities. The open source nature of the device allow it to be easily repaired or upgraded with digital files, as well as to accommodate custom sample sizes and mixing velocities with minimal additional costs.

Original designs by: Dhwani K. Trivedi

Full instructions for assembly: Dhwani K. Trivedi and Joshua M. Pearce. Open Source 3-D Printed Nutating Mixer. Applied Sciences, 2017, 7(9), 942; doi:10.3390/app7090942 https://www.academia.edu/34589801/OpenSource3-DPrintedNutating_Mixer

FreeCad Files to customize: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/open-source-nutating-mixer
More open source scientific equipment at: http://www.appropedia.org/Open-source_Lab

My collection of the best Things posted for the week of 9/11/17:
https://www.thingiverse.com/LoboCNC/collections/best-of-the-week-9-11-17

This is the fourth (and last, for the time being) week of my experiment with crowd-sourced curation. I've looked at every single Thing posted from 9/11/17 through 9/17/17 and selected what I think are the best Things according the criteria listed below. This posting here is sort of a meta-Thing to help people find this collection. Let me know what you think of this idea in the comments section.

If you like this concept, please "Like" this Thing to help others find it. You can also "Like" the collection itself. And if you really like this idea, create your own Best of the Week collection. I've tagged this with "BOTW" and would encourage others to use the same tags.

My Selection Criteria
What I look for:

  1. Things that are unique
  2. Things that are well executed
  3. Things that are of general interest
  4. Things that are well presented
  5. Things that make me smile

What I pass over:

  1. Cover images that are a rendering (i.e.: no photo of a real print)
  2. Accessories for very specific products (e.g.: for GoPro Hero, Samsung Galaxy 7, etc.)
  3. Things based on copyrighted material
  4. 3D printer parts (just too many, too specific and too boring)

description.text:
Linear guide created from the need of the economy. After some mechanical studies of the piece of aluminum I realized that it was a support for the guide that is fastened with a screw behind. As the grip is not so strong then we will have the same product.

One is with pin that centralizes the assembly, plus there is a file without the pin as well.
The spacings between the holes to hold the shaft is 150mm and I designed to use M6 bolt.
There is no recess on the opposite side of the guide because the idea is to use a through screw that will secure the table.

The total height including the pin is 190mm and should be printed on a printer with high height.

title: Improved Dollar Store Glass Bottle Cork

description.text:
A simple replacement plug/cork/bung for those handy, inexpensive bottles the Dollar Store sells. Unfortunately, the crappy corks that come with them wear out quickly under repeated use, and without them the bottles are basically useless. They also chip away at the edges making them hard to uncork.

So I designed this, which provides a better seal, is more durable, and has a handy pull tab to uncork. Intended to be printed with flexible filaments (I used Ninjaflex).

author: jeanpatrickleger

description.text:
Diagram-accurate replica of the Citadel of Ricks Badge designed based on the line art available in the "Art of Rick and Morty" art book released in September 2017.

As of today (2 days after release of book), all available models are "distorted", generally being " fat" and bulky. Some resemble or were made from screen captures but the final production art from the show deviates a lot from screen to screen as well as from the template. I whipped a version real quick to use as a basis for an Evil Morty President Badge I have also uploaded.

Printed the Rick badge on draft settings at 25% scale and the print came out fine. Part has a little indent I use to fit pins I have at home. Model printed with 20% infill, properties aren't a big issue. Just place the model flat down on the print surface with the "R" side up.
Brims and rafts aren't really necessary and will only lead to increased post-print requirements.

Thank you ZenziWerken for producing this initial drawing file. I modified the Teaching Clock by ZenziWerken by making it CNC-friendly. I also had to scale the numerals for a 1/8" end mill and add a line in the middle of the digits to allow the CNC to engrave them. The CAD work was done in AutoCAD and the DWG and DXF files are attached. The CAM work was done in CamBam which generated the attached G-code. Lastly, Mach3 software was used to 'drive' the machine.

The material used is 1/4" MDF (actual thickness is .240") which was mounted to a thin spoiler-board. There are tabs to hold the components from breaking free. I did an initial light sanding with an orbital sander before applying a clear coat of paint to seal the wood before further painting. The numerals, 5-minute, and 1-minute features are 0.09" deep and are back-filled with acrylic paint. After the paint is dried, the face of the clock is sanded again. A final layer of clear coat is applied.

Light sanding and filing is needed to get the parts to fit. I used a single-edge razor blade to lightly chamfer the edges where the two stands fit into the back of the clock and the base. CA glue (gel formula) was used to hold the components in place. After everything was dry, a final coat of clear paint was applied over the whole assembly. Next came the #10-24 hex head screw along with some misc. nylon washers I had in my parts bin. The Hands are separated with a nylon washer and a nylon washer is placed under the retaining nut. A nyloc-nut was used to hold the hands together and has tightened to apply enough friction to hold the hands in place when set.

The attached NC file (G-code) has the depth set at 0.09" depth increments with a final depth of 0.255". The feed rate is set kind-of slow at 10 IPM due to issues with my DIY CNC machine (which will be resolved at a later date). The router is a DeWatt 611 with variable speed which was set to #1 (16K RPM). The end mill is a 0.125" in an adapter to fit the collet of the router.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117519

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=117519

Using the following options:

Text_Rotate = 0
Your_Text = Tanner`s gokart
Text_Size = 4
Text_Font = write/orbitron.dxf

It seems that many of my things I'll be giving as Christmas presents this year are small, less then a few inches in dimensions. That brings up the question, How do I pack it? One could put the thing in a envelope or a small plastic bag, but all of those like a distinct "giftiness", they don't really look like a gift. Enter the Folded Box, it's small enough to print and/or cut from a piece of standard size card stock. You can also easily customize it with a logo or name to make it that much cooler. The box is cut from a single sheet of material. Thick paper, card stock and poster board work well. This pattern will not work well with corrugated cardboard since the thickness of it will make the folds difficult to make. There are two sizes: The 7x8 pattern produces a final box that is about: 2.5 x 2.5 x 1 inches inside.
The 8x8 pattern produces a final box that is about: 3.5 x 2.5 x 1 inches inside. If you are interested in more of my stuff check out: http://4volt.com

This box can be cut in two ways, both are easy:

  • Printed the pattern on card stock, then cut with a scissor

  • Cut directly with a laser
    • If you want to add your own logo or name on the lid of the box, remember to place it upside down on the lid part of the pattern. With the logo upside down, the bottom of it will face the front of the box. No glue, tape or other bonding is required, the folding of the box locks all the other folds in place. To assemble: I've found if you crease all the fold marks with a ruler you'll end up with a box that is easier to fold and looks more crisp. If you've ever assembled shipping boxes you'll already know how to assemble this box. Although if you never have I've labeled the folds in order in the "Box Folding Diagram".

  • Fold the tabs inwards

  • Fold the front and back wall vertical to the bottom of the box

  • Fold the #3 side walls vertical

  • Fold the #4 walls around tab #1, and insert the small tab on #4 into the slit in the bottom of the box. This will lock all the walls in place

  • Fold the lid tabs in, having tabs on all edges of the lit will keep the lit flat

  • Fold the box lid and the #5 tabs inside the walls of the box.

title: Thrust Meter Stand from Kitchen Scale

description.text:
Think this is the proudest make for me on thingiverse ever.

This uses the most widely available cheap kitchen scale with a 5kg load cell in it. (as attached pic). If you have a different kitchen scale with similar spec, it's possible too, distance between the 2 screw of the load cell mount is 10mm, let me know if yours differ, I'll modify the file for you. FYI my load cell measures 75mm(L) x 12.5mm(W) x 12.5mm(H) in size.

NOTE

  • Highly recommended to print the Thrust Stand at 100% infill
  • I'm not a mechanical engineer, not sure what's the strength thrust this can take so do not go over 2kg thrust test
  • Highly recommended to mount this permanently onto your table!
  • If you can't, mount it on a thick kitchen chopping board, then clamp it onto the table
  • I don't recommend printing the motor mount, make it out of 2mm alu plate. the file accepts 16mm, 19mm and 25mm format.

ALWAYS WEAR PROTECTIVE GEAR such as GOGGLE and long sleeve whenever you perform full throttle test! It's not funny. Anything can go wrong at those speed, unbalanced prop could wreck your stand, wires may be sucked to your prop(it happened).

If I'm free then maybe I'll make a nice enclosure like this. Or if DIY is hard for you, get this for USD93 only!
https://go.edwardrc.com/2DjeJzp

Parts list
Weighing scale/Kitchen scale
https://go.edwardrc.com/2DjfhVZ

To make it better, get a Power Analyzer!
https://go.edwardrc.com/2mrKU8q

2x AA battery holder
https://go.edwardrc.com/2D4ZJbi

One of the most recommended printer now
http://bit.ly/2zB1Vlp

Assembly,

  1. First print the stand, print it front facing down for strength, but upright is fine too
  2. Remove the guts from your kitchen scale
  3. De-solder the 4 wires of load cell from the board (take a pic of the board first!)
  4. Slide the Two M4 screw into the stand, use a twizzer to put 4 washer over it(comes with it)
  5. Tricky. Push the screw against the wall so it retains the washer there
  6. Slot in the load cell 4 wires from top, carefully pull the wires through the bottom hole while you insert the load cell and align with the 2 screw hole
    • PLS note the FORCE direction of the load cell, there should be a sticker on top
  7. Screw it! Screw them...
  8. Now load 3 M3 lock nut into those legs. Press fit easily
  9. Now mount it on your preferred table or base such as chopping board
  10. Mount your motor mount onto the load cell
  11. Solder the load cell wires to your board and arrange the board, display, buttons to your creativity

Micromake Delta

Print as is.

author: MungoBBQ

title: E3D-v5 Fan Dual Assembly for Makergear M2

description.text:
UPDATE: I recently posted an update to this (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:533029). Please check this out for the latest version, which I think performs better and does last much longer. I've been using the new nozzle design for over 3 months without any sign of warping. So please use the new design as the old one does warp after a month or so of use.
.
This is an E3D fan solution for the MakerGear M2. This has built-in supports so should require minimal cleanup. I was inspired by an Ultimaker E3D mount model, which I think is an elegant and effective design:
.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:121074
.
Even though it's not a true remix, I borrowed a few concepts.
I modified the model of a E3D v4 fan duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52506) to keep the fan and hot end consistently oriented, I etched lettering to identify nozzle diameter, and added an attachment point for the larger fan duct.
.
I've encountered very few problems with this design. You may have to work a bit to get the E3D installed on the filament guide as it is a tight fit with the restrictor plate in place. I've been testing this for about three months and I've not had any fail due to warping. Although expect this to warp with time as with most cooling ducts. It should not affect performance though.
.
Further, E3D recently made design changes to the heater blocks that affect the position of the heater cartridge and nozzle. I'm sharing photos of the differences between the old and new blocks. I've retooled the design to also fit the new block (version 2). So before printing, please identify the version of the block you have. They are very different.
.
You may need to bump up your melt temps a bit (~10-15°C) and or reduce your cooling to 20% (45% max).
.
EDIT: I uploaded a new set of Ducts. The "b" version has a slightly shorter restrictor plate at the top of the duct so it is easier to install the hot end into the filament guide. And I uploaded a version of the duct without the restrictor plate - "E3D Duct wo Plate.stl".

Print the version of the nozzle that matches your hot end block (see photo). The modified E3D fan duct has support built-in so print all parts without support.
I've included versions of the E3D duct with nozzle diameter sizes engraved for easy identification. I also included a plain one in case you'd rather have a plain face.
Assembly is pretty straight forward. Pass the E3D hot end (with thermistor and heater cartridge installed) onto the E3D duct. Bolt the nozzle onto the E3D duct using 2 22mm M3 bolts. I've tinkered with the part dimensions so they should fit together without fine tuning. The whole assembly fits onto the filament guide pretty tightly so may be a bit tricky but it does fit.
I recommend using a Noctua 40X10mm A-series fan. They are very quiet and emits no vibration buzz that cheaper fans can.
While I marked this as a work in progress, I think it is pretty complete but if you have requests / suggestions for improvements, just drop a comment. Good luck with this. I hope it helps you make better prints.

comments.author: Neo_Usagi

comments.text: No worries... The E3D duct is based on a stock duct (the latest one I could find). It works with all the E3D heatsinks I've purchased (I own 4). How I handled the different blocks was by modifying the nozzle. Version 2 of the nozzle is for the more centered block. This repositions the block by several mm which makes a big difference in how close the hot end comes to the nozzle. I hope this helps and definitely, I hope this works for you and the rest of the Robo3D community.

author: gee38l

description.text:
In case you're not using a fixed leadscrew, it's advisable to fix the z-axis using a bearing.
I've remixed the z-motor piece to fit a 608 flanged bearing. Diameter fits an 8mm lead screw. Designed to be mounted on 3030 extrusion profiles.
See pictures how to mount it.
Enjoy, Peter

PS : tested on : https://www.thingiverse.com/make:354798

comments.text:
It's been my experience that constraining both ends of a lead screw tends to lead to greater Z-wobble. I've tried it on a couple printers, and it made things much worse, and others have noted the same thing. If your lead-screw has wobble in it, constraining the end will move that wobble to the middle where your nut is, causing your bed to move in small circles for each turn of the lead screw. If the end is not constrained, the end is allowed to wobble, while the bed is held it place by the linear rails. This makes for better prints.
I've tested also, solid coupling to the motor (with and without end constraint), and spring coupling, which allows the rod to bend a little bit. The best results were with a spring coupler, and no end constraints. Solid couplers with even slightly bent lead screws, as many are, add z-wobble on the part. The worst is with solid couplers, or integrated screws, with end constraints like your part. If your lead screws are perfectly straight it's ok, but in that case you won't have a wobble problem anyway.
comments.author: jsondag

comments.text:
I have had the opposite experience. I found the spring type held the lead screw off center, then when the top was held I had bad Z wobble so I took that off for a while...
I found a self centering coupler that solved that and my z problems went away 75% I added a fanged bearing to hold the top and my Z and got to maybe 90% then I put in TMC2100 drivers and every axis is perfect now. No detectable Z deflection in prints even looking at it under high magnification.
comments.author: jsondag

comments.text: I second this json, adding a mount to the top, forces the bed to follow any non-true movement in the rods, which translates to terrible z wobble. The only way to eliminate z-wobble, is to add a way to absorb any movement on the nut-mount, so it doesn't translate directly to the bed.
comments.author: jsondag

this is my version of the DDC pump bracket attached to the 140mm fan. Housing is a Enthoo Primo. The water pump is additionally cooled from below via a 50mm fan. was designed with support at the big hole

I kept running into the problem that I didnt have enough room under the prusa i2 to put the electronics and power supply, so I just built these. Just print 4, print the adjustable feet found here, 4 of them also and replace those with the feet vertexes that you usually have on your printer with these ones here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:108841. I used 4 6 inch pieces of 5/16 threaded rod from the vertexes to the feet pieces, then just cut the other pieces to size after putting everything together. I didnt use any washers on the bottom row because they go past the bottom of the feet. Ive been using this for a little while, and I havnt had an trouble with any wobble, the frame is very sturdy, and you dont have to worry about the thing tipping either way while printing either. I just stuck on these rubber feet that you stick on to each of the feet, and they everything is rock solid while everything is running.

title: Halloween wristband (TPU)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A flexible wristband printed with TPU for Halloween (instead of sweets!). The straps can be cut to whatever length is suitable to the wearer. Ideally two locking pads (and holes) should be available within the desired strap length.

UPDATE: I have added a file specifically for printing in nylon. I have reduced the base layer to just 0.5mm thick to keep it flexible. Nylon is very tough and will hold together at such a thin layer. TPU can be difficult to load due to its extreme flexibility but nylon loads easily. The skull motif is sharper in nylon but TPU is the better option.

title: Anet A6/A8 Y-Axis Support with Belt Tensioner

description.text:
This Anet A6/A8 Y-Axis support uses 2 pieces of 8mm threaded rod, length roughly 313mm and 353mm respectively and 4 pieces of 8mm nuts.

You can do away your 3d printed Front and Back support braces, and just use this instead. No drilling to your existing acrylic frame.

There is a version A and version B due to different size of 8mm nuts. As these nut needs to be sit right in the frame. Version B is designed for stock Anet 8mm nut as the stainless steel nut I bought tend to be a bit smaller (Version A)

Design that allow adjustment can be loosen by itself due to printing vibration from my experience that is why I opt for captive nuts.

It also comes with 2 version of Y-axis belt holder.

comments.text: YES. That is the reason why the nut size must fit correctly.  And that is how the Y structure is lock and prevent any self adjustment during normal printing cause by vibration.  Had tried the adjustable designed and found this fixed lock nut design to be far better.  Because it just need to be installed right once and it stay and maintain its rigidity.   Design that allow adjustment can be loosen by itself due to printing vibration from my experience that is why I opt for captive nuts.
comments.author: chekcian

comments.text: Looks like a better design than the y-axis rework...however having the nuts captured like that means you have to set them perfectly before putting them in rather than being able to adjust them on the frame.  I would suggest allowing for some adjustment.
comments.author: InspGadgt

comments.text: The green support is not necessary.  I just added that to prevent my acrylic from being scratch by the m4 tensioning screw.  You can just place a m3 nut at the tip of the m4 screw.  The support uses m8 threaded rod and nut.  Just print out the front support A or B to determine your m8 nut fit Type A or B.  My stock A6 m8 nut uses Type B whereas the m8 nuts I bought from local supplier tend to be a bit smaller, Type A.  The m8 nut must fit exactly or you have difficulty in installing them
comments.author: chekcian

comments.text:
Stainless steel/ plated nuts are slightly smaller than non stainless steel nuts. The printer comes with the cheapest possible option your hardware store sold you nicer ones.
I have nylock nuts these are the same size as the stainless or plated nuts. Printing the parts while typing this will see how it goes looks like a good mod was wondering if 2 8mm threaded rods are really necessary wouldn't a version of this frame brace with 1 do the trick?
comments.author: chekcian

comments.text: I think one of the parts is missing. In the third picture there is a green part on the outside next to the two axis idler holders, which appears to have a nut in it. That part is not in the zip file. Can you update the files? Also, what are the specs for the nuts & bolts? The threaded rod looks like it's 8mm in diameter, is that correct?

title: Extruder for J-head hotend (not for Prusa)

description.text:
Note: This will NOT fit a standard Prusa i3 (or anything else that I know of). It is a unfinished but working device under development. An extruder for a custom 3D-printer I'm building.
Runs on 10mm rods spaced 45mm apart.
Work in progress, more to come.
  • NEMA 17 stepper motor.
  • J-head hotend
  • Mk8 direct drive gear
  • LM10UU bearings
  • M3 and M4 bolts to attach the different parts together
    • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aeNzqg9F5qU http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YblmajDrg9I Edit April 6th 2014: Updated files to revision 2, major changes:
  • Added a support bar between the rear of the LM10UU-bearing holders, which added a lot of rigidity.
  • Added 2mm to the motor mount thickness
  • Strengthened the J-head mount by adding more material in certain places
  • Added a lower cradle for the J-head, as well as a cradle on the J-head mount piece to avoid wobbling printhead.
  • Small change to the filament tightening nut access.
Made in Solidworks

comments.text: You would have a lot of instability in the movement due to only running a single bearing per rod.
comments.author: DirtySteve

comments.text: Would this be because of sideways wobble? I considered switching to LM10LUU-bearings for this reason, but I figured I'd try the shorter ones first. The LM10LUU bearings add 26mm to the length, so I could see where it would give significantly more stability.
comments.author: DirtySteve

comments.text: haha i suggested the same thing, but its too late in the build to do that, plus  i realized it would lowere his extruder position which makes his print area less
comments.author: daewootech

comments.text: Yeah, I did a quick check now, and it would take 27.5 mm of the Z height to just fit the NEMA17 in there, and I would also have trouble fitting the two timing belts anywhere intelligent.
comments.author: daewootech

comments.text:
Very nice and compact.
Now move the nema in between the two straight rods, attaching the belt to the center of mass of the nema.
comments.author: TakeItAndRun

comments.text: ThanksI'm using the space between the rods to run the belts (this is designed to have two extruders working independently on the axis). I might see if I can make room for it, but then it would take quite a bit of the max Z-height of the printer.

title: Cigarette disposal station
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi,

The pins and knobs are printed at 102% size with PLA. The pins should be printed flat with support at 50% infill. the knobs should be printed flat side down without support, also at 102% size.

the top plate is printed with PETG for flexibility. it is easier to work with for emptying the can.
it is printed at 100% size, 0.8 wall, no infill.

Reminder that plastics are flammable. add some water at the bottom of the can for extra protection. You can also glue an aluminium plate inside the top plate.

This setup was designed to fit the coffee cans we have and the railing at my house.

Can diameter 157mm
railing post 26mm

title: Quadrant (Sexstant predecessor) - Celestial navigation - NO Supports

description.text:
I am always been a fan of old navigation techinque and I really like to use a Sexstant to find my position on earth. This instrument, the Quadrant, is the predecessor of the Sexstant and it really usefull if you like to calculate altitude of mountains or distance from a certain object and even to calculate your position on earth by using it in cobination with a normal clock.

I've uploaded a simple guide on how to use it with some examples.

The hardware you need:

  • 1, M4 x 25 mm Screw (link to buy it: https://www.amazon.com/Stainless-Steel-Phillips-Round-Screws/dp/B012TCNAD0)
  • 3, M4 Nuts (link to buy them: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Full-Stainless-Steel-Hexagon-Delivery/dp/B00A6G5H0G)
  • 3, M4 Washer (link tou buy them: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Washer-4-3mm-Stainless-Washers-Delivery/dp/B00A6PILR8)
  • 2, MF104ZZ Flanged ball bearings (link to buy the bearings: https://www.banggood.com/10pcs-MF104ZZ-4x10x4mm-Metal-Shielded-Flange-Ball-Bearings-p-1147094.html)

How to assemble the quadrant and how I made it: https://youtu.be/rKAefZo1f6w

As always CAD files are uploaded so you can modify my design to fit your needs.

If you have a similar size flanged ball bearing:

  • FUSION 360:
    open the "Stellar_Quadrant_v32.f3d" --> change parameters --> edit the parameters to match the dimensions of you bearing.

  • IF YOU DON'T HAVE FUSION 360:
    Write me in the comment the type and the dimensions of your flanged ball bearing and I will upload as soon as possible the stl file with the changes that you asked.

It assembles and settles on stalks thread by structure of Anet A8. It is designed to assemble on the printer while taking into account the constraints of geometry and not to prevent the use of the printer.

The assemble is flexible: boxes are identical except the size of the compartment and drawers can be thus assembled on both boxes.

comments.text:
I love the idea. Very cool and easy to print.
Unfortunately it doesn’t fit to the 2017 Anet A8. Clashes with the heatbed bearings. :(
The threaded rods fit well. The other rods fits too, but it’s already critical. The bearings doesn’t fit at all. The cut-outs are too small and the box is too high. Don’t know, maybe they’ve changed the bearings.
Other than this. There’s enough space to assemble this box and Leo’s frame brace as well. I’ve thickened the front and rear wall of the box by 5mm each. The box is a bit more robust, and box (in front) plus frame brace (behind) fits tight in between front frame and middle bow. No chance for bending anymore.

description.text:
This custom dispensing head is developed for a FABtotum machine (http://www.fabtotum.com). In this video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sfShcG9ttyo) an example of solder paste dispensing on PCB is presented. See here also the communication test of the dispensing head with FABtotum: https://youtu.be/Y6b74WLYMg0. The example PCB is an FTDI circuit (http://archive.fabacademy.org/2016/fablabsingapore/students/98/exercise06.html) designed with KiCAD (1206 Imperial). The PCB is also milled with FABtotum using FlatCAM. An 20G 0.6mm ID 1.5'' dispensing needle is used to dispense diluted solder paste with IPA:

-Custom dispensing head is 3D printed with FABtotum.
-CAD files for dispensing head of TwinTeeth (http://www.diyouware.com/node/174) were adapted for FABtotum.
-Electronics consist of an Arduino Nano v3 with our firmware in order to control a 28BYJ-48-5V step motor with a ULN2003 driver.
-CAM software rpt2pnp (https://github.com/hzeller/rpt2pnp) was adapted to fit the needs of FABtotum.

Find all needed information (CAD files, Arduino firmware and CAM software) by clicking download button. You need also to print HDB support for FABtotum (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1896425).

Printer:

FABtotum

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm layer height

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Used FABtotum black ABS material.

-3D printing: print all downloaded parts and the HDB support for FABtotum.
-Buying: FABtotum HDB kit, Arduino Nano v3, 28BYJ-48-5V, ULN2003, lead free solder paste, Isopropyl alcohol (IPA), M5 lead screw (pitch 0.8 mm).
-Firmware: Load .ino file to Arduino Nano.
-Integration: Connect all printed parts with screws, couplers, etc (more information in TwinTeeth). Then connect the dispenser with HDB support, the aluminium plate and the PCB of HDB kit with supplied screws. Add the electronics on the printed plate and connect them with cables (more information in HDB of FABtotum).
-CAM: Build supplied source code with "make" and generate .gcode and .ps files using your KiCAD rpt file as input (more information in rpt2pnp).
-Solder paste: Dilute lead free solder paste (keep safety measures) with IPA.
-Dispensing: Actions and meaning of commands can be found in supplied .ino file of Arduino Nano. Move in Jog page of FABtotum's fabui-colibri OS the needle right above the first pad of your PCB (see .ps file). Take generated gcode, paste it in the Jog page and execute it.

-The parts that were modified from TwinTeeth have Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License, which is marked in Basic Information.
-The modified rpt2pnp code has GNU General Public License v3.0
-The Arduino .ino file has GNU General Public License v3.0
-The parts 3_PlateToConnectToFABtotum.stl and 7_washer.stl have Creative Commons Attribution License.

-Lower the syringe and use 0.5 inch (instead of 1.5) syringe needle (or conical syringe tip), in order to reduce the pressure drop during paste extrusion. That would mean to cut the aluminium plate of HDB in order to lower the syringe.
-Thicken the Arduino Nano placeholder because it is easy to break.
-Modify CAM software in order to perform some dummy dispenses automatically, before starting dispensing on PCB, and make quicker movements.
-Build a pick and place head for a FABtotum machine.

I was tired of adjusting the Z stop and guessing how many turns i needed to get a good result. Thus I created this super fine adjusting Z-stop. I made two versions for the switch mount (One with a power switch to turn the printer on, and one without. You need a micrometer for this and you need to cut off the end of it to make it fit. I used a cheap 25mm micrometer from ebay that was $7. Just use a metal hacksaw or chop saw to cut of the end of it, but make sure you leave the two mounting points. Here is a link to the micrometer I used: http://www.ebay.com/itm/252946596198 if you want to use the power switch version, you just need a 16mm push button switch such as this: http://www.ebay.com/itm/141700412231 This works well because you can adjust the Zstop very well and lock it in place when you find that sweet spot!

title: Z probe fixture for Reach 3D printer with fine adjustment

description.text:
This Z probe fixture is designed for the Reach 3D printer. For 12 mm diameter Z probe. The mechanical hinge design allows for fine adjustment with no backlash. Best printed in ABS which is a little more flexible than PLA. One M3 screw is needed for the vertical adjustment. Pre-tension the Z probe holder as shown in the picture. With print head in zero position mount the Z probe to roughly the correct position, then fine tune with the M3 screw.
For retaining the Z probe in the holder a clip is integrated in the design. If this wears or does not print correct an optional M3 screw can be used to lock the Z probe in place.

Printer:

Reach 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Printed in ABS, heating bed required with temperature > 80 °C.
Printed in PLA works too although the mechanical hinges will be less flexible. Moving them a couple of times by hand will make them less stiff.
After slicing I checked that the print flow is continuous across the thin hinge sections, if this is not the cause the hinges will be weak.
Printed parts was aceton vapor smoothened.This seems to make the hinge more flexible even after completely cured.

Designed in Onshape. (files are public)
Designed to fit the Reach 3D hot end bracket in combination with click on fan ducts as shown in photo.

remixed_from.title: Anti-vibration feet for GEEETech i3 Pro B with 8mm acrylic frame

description.text:
This is a remix of Spotz's Vibration damper!

After printing his great damper with support material, I realized the support material inside the slot is almost impossible to remove...
(Yes, you don't have to worry about this if you can manually set the support structure by using Simplify3D or similar)
So, I've separated the damper with two parts like XDr4g0nX's vibration feet :3

Use M4 x 8mm bolts and M4 nuts to hold them in place!
You can adjust the orientation of the feet slightly.

Also, you don't have to mirror these parts because they have symmetrical design!
Just print and use!

Printer:

Geeetech MeCreator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.05mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

with 0.2mm layer height, 3 perimeters and 5mm brim.

PLA works fine even if I put 1kg filament on the printer.
ABS is also working nicely, but huge brim might be needed. (I've tried both of them)

title: Magnetic Building Board Lever Clamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Magnetic stand-off clamp for model builders that use a magnetic building board.

It uses common cabinet magnet latch magnets. Here is one source: https://www.allelectronics.com/item/mag-123/cabinet-latch-magnet/1.html

EDIT: 02/04/2018 The above magnets appear to be sold out. Regular ceramic rectangles will work too. A source is here: https://supermagnetman.com/collections/fer-rectangle/products/rect0750c-20?variant=29741050307

They are listed as "0.770" (19.56mm) long x 0.593" (15.06mm) wide x 0.118" (3mm) thick". Use two sandwiched together in place of the above latch magnets if you can't find the originals.

The arm is threaded for a M4 screw thread but there is enough material there to rethread it to any reasonable size. The lever arm slides into the slotted bracket. This setup can produce a lot of downward force.

See my magnetic building board 90 degree triangle brace here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2540801

title: USB microscope stand with x-y base and built-in backlight

description.text:
My daughter tried to use a USB microscope, but it was difficult. Keeping focus at high magnification is hard and moving viewed samples is also not easy.
So I designed a table for her, helpful in shifting the sample and focusing.
I also added a backlight crucial for some microscope slides.

Thanks! to 'Hank-Cowdog' for sharing the knob design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:664192) – it was the basis for code for x/y/z knobs.

Film demonstrating how the table works - https://youtu.be/JszwZvKry9o.
In the gallery few bonus photos with our "cat" :)

Features
  • fine adjustment for precise focusing
  • built in x-y stage with fine adjustment
  • built in LED backlight powered via USB
  • clips for holding objects being viewed
  • easy replaceable microscope holder; holder for Bresser Junior hand-held USB microscope
  • stage dimension (L x W): 90 mm x 70 mm; fits for standard microscope slides 75 mm by 25 mm
Bill of materials
Smooth and threaded rods
  • 2 x smooth rod Ø6x115 mm (for the X-axis)
  • 2 x smooth rod Ø6x95 mm (for the Y-axis)
  • 2 x smooth rod Ø6x100 mm (for the Z-axis)
  • 1 x threaded rod M3x160 mm (for the X-axis)
  • 1 x threaded rod M3x120 mm (for the Y-axis)
  • 1 x threaded rod M3x120 mm (for the Z-axis)
Screws, nuts and washers
  • 30 x M3 nut
  • 30 x M3 washer
  • 2 x M4x14 bolt
  • 1 x M4 nut
  • 2 x M4 wing nut
  • 4 x M2x10 screw
Electronics
  • USB cable
  • 5 x LED 3mm white (20 mA, 3,1V drop)
  • 2 x 39Ω 0.25W resistor
  • 1 x PCB protoboard 22 mm x 37 mm
Other
  • 1 x translucent sheet 90 mm x 70 mm (for the stage cover); e.g. cut from the windshield washer bottle
Printing
  • PLA
  • infill 20%
  • support on

description.text:
This is a double-height (6mm) bed mount for a 240mm Kossel Plus printer bed (2020 extrusion). It is designed to accommodate a 240mm heater plate as well as the 240mm glass (both 3mm thick).

It should be printed in ABS with 100% infill for maximum rigidity.

You will also require (for each side, so 3x):

  • M3 Tap Tool
  • M3 Bolts (~10mm long) x 2
  • M4+ bolts and captive nuts x 2

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Update:
The clamp had badly formed screw holes. This has been updated.

Tap the screw holes

The base unit has two 2.5mm holes that need to be tapped with an M3x0.5 tap. This allows the clamp to be directly screwed down with M3 bolts.

(ESP) Este diseño lo llevo puliendo hace mas de 2 años, es el resultado de muchas experiencias, diseños y modificaciones que le hicimos a este robot cuadrupedo basico durante todos estos meses.

Ahora lo publico para poder compartirlo con todos ustedes.

Para realizar este robot, hay que imprimir:
1-Base
8-Ues de los servos
4-Patas
1-Tapa de pilas
1-Pares superior
1-Tapa Superior

Actualizacion de Piezas 03/10/2017 <<<
Subí las piezas de Base, u y patas para su utilziacion con los servos MG90.
Dichas piexzas estan debidamente nombradas para su identificacion, con lo cual, si quieren armar este robot con los servos comunes azules SG90, no utilicen las piezas nombradas con MG90. Gracias!

Los componentes necesarios para construir este robot son:
1-Arduino Nano
1-Shield Arduino nano
1-Step Down
1-Llave Switch
8-Servo SG90
2-Baterias 18650
1-Cables varios para conectar bateria
8-Tornillos extras para las tapas

Interesados en el codigo, puden tomar de ejeplo el codigo que subi en github:
https://github.com/Konredus

Interesados en conocer mas de lo que hago, visitar mi perfil de instagram:
https://www.instagram.com/konredus/

//---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(ENG) This design has been polished more than 2 years ago, is the result of many experiences, designs and modifications that we made to this basic quadruped robot during all these months.

Now I publish it so I can share it with all of you.

To make this robot, you have to print:
1-Base
8-Servo U's
4-Legs
1-Battery cover
1-Top wall
1-Top Cover

Updating Parts 03/10/2017 <<<
I uploaded the base parts, u and legs for use with MG90 servos.
These pieces are duly named for identification, so if you want to assemble this robot with the common blue servos SG90, do not use the parts named with MG90. Thank you!

The components needed to build this robot are:
1-Arduino Nano
1-Shield Arduino nano
1-Step-Down
1-o¡On off Switch
8-Servo SG90
2-18650 Batteries
1-Various cables to connect battery
8-Screws extra for the covers

Interested in the code, you can take the code that I uploaded in github:
https://github.com/Konredus

Interested in learning more about what I do, visit my instagram profile:
https://www.instagram.com/konredus/
